questions.question:
Question 1: An 18-month-old child is brought to OPD with complaints of blood in his urine. Examination 
reveals a non-tender mass in the left flank that does not cross the midline. Blood pressure is 
also found to be elevated. Imaging reveals a left renal tumor and surgical resection is 
planned. The gross appearance of the mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing a well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, 
hemorrhagic, and cystic changes in the upper pole of the kidney are suggestive of 
a nephroblastoma or Wilms' tumor. It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 years of age). Around 10% of cases 
are associated with genetic syndromes and gonadal dysgenesis may be seen. Clinical manifestations of Wilms' tumor include: • Large abdominal mass - usually unilateral and does not cross the midline • Abdominal pain • Hematuria • Hypertension • Intestinal obstruction (in some cases) 826 
Sold by @itachibot Nephrogenic rests are the precursor lesions of Wilms' tumor and suggest an increased risk of 
developing a contralateral Wilms' tumor.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is true regarding Wilms tumor?

options.a: It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
options.b: It is associated with MIC-2 gene expression
options.c: It is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13
options.d: The most common presentation is hematuria

questions.explanation:
Wilms' tumor is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The most common clinical presentation is an abdominal 
mass. Note: MIC-2 gene expression is seen in neuroblastoma.

questions.question:
Question 3: In patients with Wilms tumors, which of the following microscopic features are indicative of 
resistance to chemotherapy?
questions.explanation:
In Wilms' tumor, the presence of anaplasia is indicative of resistance to chemotherapy. This correlates with the presence of TP53 mutations and, hence, is associated with a poor 
prognosis.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor?
questions.explanation:
Anaplastic histology is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor. It is seen in about 5% of cases and is characterized by the presence of cells with large, 
hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei, and abnormal mitoses. It is associated with TP53 mutations 
and resistance to chemotherapy. Anaplasia is uncommon in children < 2 years. Hence, tumors presenting at an young age have a 
significantly better prognosis than those presenting in older children. Prognostic factors in Wilms' tumor include: Favorable prognosis 
Adverse prognosis Anaplastic histology Histologic type

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not associated with Wilms tumor?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilms tumor. 827 
Sold by @itachibot Wilms' tumor can be associated with: • Aniridia - WAGR syndrome • Gonadal dysgenesis - Denys–Drash syndrome • Hemihypertrophy and omphalocele - Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome

questions.question:
Question 6: A 16-year-old girl is being evaluated for a history of recurrent seizures and abdominal 
discomfort. Examination reveals the following nail findings. Which of the following should 
she be screened for? 819 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing periungual fibromas are strongly suggestive of tuberous 
sclerosis. This condition is associated with renal angiomyolipomas (present in 25–50% of cases). Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of 
inheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 
9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16. The clinical features of tuberous sclerosis include: • Skin lesions - • Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules • Periungual fibromas or Koenen tumors (small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or 
toenails) • Shagreen patch- roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, primarily in the 
lumbosacral region • Facial angiofibromas • Confetti skin lesions • Neurological features - • Epilepsy and intellectual disability (due to cortical tubers) • Autism spectrum disorder • Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas • Other tumors - • Cardiac rhabdomyoma • Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis Angiomyolipoma is a benign renal neoplasm (hamartoma) originating from perivascular 
epithelioid cells (PEComa). It consists of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat in variable proportions. 
They are highly susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage. The histological image of renal angiomyolipoma is given below: 828 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 50-year-old diabetic patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal discomfort. CECT of 
the abdomen and pelvis shows a heterogeneously enhancing renal mass with a central stellate 
scar. On resection, the tumor appears mahogany brown. What is the site of origin of this 
tumor?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history is suggestive of renal oncocytoma. It arises from the intercalated cells of 
the collecting ducts. It is a benign epithelial neoplasm. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahogany 
brown and relatively homogeneous. They are usually well encapsulated with a central scar in 
one-third of cases. Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, 
benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have 
numerous mitochondria. The gross and histological appearances of renal oncocytoma are shown in the images given below: 829 
Sold by @itachibot 830 
Sold by @itachibot Oncocytes refer to epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to the 
accumulation of mitochondria). They can arise in various tissues and are referred to as: • Hurthle cells/Ashkenazy cells in the thyroid gland • Oxyphilic cells in the parotid gland • Apocrine metaplasia in the breast

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the 
papillary type of renal tumor?
questions.explanation:
The most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor is the 
size of the tumor. The papillary type of renal tumors includes: • Renal papillary adenoma ( 1.5 cm) • Papillary type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - > 1.5 cm Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and incidentally found. Ruling out of malignancy 
is one of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys. Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the second most common type of renal cell carcinoma and 
it arises from proximal tubules. It can be multifocal or bilateral. It is typically hemorrhagic and 
cystic, especially when large. It is often a circumscribed tumor composed of papillae formed by delicate fibrovascular cores that 
often contain foamy macrophages and Psammoma bodies. It has two histological types: • Type 1 papillary RCC - single layer of cells on the basement membrane and low-grade nuclear 
features 831 
Sold by @itachibot • Type 2 papillary RCC - pseudostratification of cells and usually has high-grade nuclear features

questions.question:
Question 9: The following image shows a nephrectomy specimen of a patient diagnosed with renal cell 
carcinoma. What is the likely histopathological finding in this tumor?

options.c: Small cells with high N/C ratio

questions.explanation:
The given image shows a bright yellow variegated mass distorting the renal outline at the lower 
pole. This is suggestive of the clear cell type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The yellow color is due 
to prominent lipid accumulation. Gross findings of various types of renal tumors: Clear-cell RCC

questions.question:
Question 10: The nephrectomy specimen of a tumor of a 40-year-old man shows the following histological 
presentation. Which of the following familial cancer syndromes is this condition associated 
with? 821 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome

questions.explanation:
The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo, 
which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associated 
with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome. Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are: • Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC • Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-like 
eosinophilic nucleoli. • Tuberous sclerosis - clear-cell RCC • Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCC The image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC. 832 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma is matched incorrectly with its 
respective cytogenetic patterns?

options.c: Hereditary papillary RCC - loss of Y
options.d: Sporadic papillary RCC - loss of Y

questions.explanation:
Loss of Y chromosome is a feature of sporadic papillary carcinoma, not hereditary papillary RCC. 833 
Sold by @itachibot Various types of renal carcinoma and their cytogenetic abnormalities are given below: • Papillary renal cell carcinoma - • Sporadic type - trisomies 7 and 17, loss of Y chromosome • Familial type - trisomy 7 (mapped to MET gene) • Clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma (whether familial, sporadic, or associated with VHL syndrome) • Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3, which harbors the VHL gene

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma, 
accounting for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers. It is most likely to arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions. It has a 
characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein. The histological features are: • Rounded or polygonal tumor cells • Abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids • Arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular pattern The histological appearance of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is shown in the image given below: 834 
Sold by @itachibot Note: The Furhman nuclear grading system was previously used for histological grading of RCC 
(except chromophobe RCC). It is now replaced by the WHO/International Society of Urologic 
Pathology (ISUP) grading system.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following tumors does not have papillary architecture on histopathology?
questions.explanation:
Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient renal cell carcinoma does not show papillary 
architecture. It is associated with a bubbly appearance of histopathology. It is a malignant epithelial tumor associated with germline mutations in the SDH gene. It 
is composed of vacuolated, eosinophilic-clear cells arranged in a solid, nested, or tubular pattern. 
The presence of the vacuoles imparts the characteristic bubbly appearance, as shown below. 835 
Sold by @itachibot Renal cell carcinoma subtypes with papillary architecture in histology: • Papillary renal cell carcinoma • Hereditary leiomyomatosis renal cell carcinoma • Xp11 translocation renal cell carcinoma • Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having a 
plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo on histological examination?
questions.explanation:
Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having plant-cell-like appearance with a 
perinuclear halo. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels. 836 
Sold by @itachibot Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma can differentiated from oncocytoma and clear cell RCC as 
follows: • Oncocytoma does not show perinuclear halo whereas chromophobe RCC shows perinuclear halo • CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC but it is negative in clear-cell RCC. Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia. The histological image of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is given below:

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is found to have a renal tumor and malignancy is 
suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the renal tumor 
associated with this condition?

options.a: It constitutes 5% of all renal tumors
options.b: Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses
options.d: It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct

questions.explanation:
The renal tumor commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is chromophobe renal cell 
carcinoma (RCC). It has an excellent prognosis. It constitutes 5% of all renal carcinomas. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting 
duct. Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses and extreme 
hypodiploidy. The histological image of chromophobe RCC is given below: 837 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following tumors characteristically shows a hobnail pattern on microscopy?
questions.explanation:
Collecting duct carcinoma or Bellini duct carcinoma shows a characteristic hobnail pattern and 
prominent desmoplastic stroma on microscopy. The hobnail pattern refers to the bulbous nuclear projections of epithelial cells that protrude into 
the lumen as little bumps. It is associated with tubular, tubulopapillary, or tubulocystic pattern. Collecting duct carcinoma arises from the principal cells of the renal collecting ducts of 
Bellini. The majority of these tumors are associated with poor outcome, due to their highly 
aggressive clinical course. The histological section showing collecting duct carcinoma with the characteristic hobnail pattern 
is given below: 838 
Sold by @itachibot Note: The hobnail pattern is also seen in clear cell carcinoma of the ovary.

questions.question: Question 17: Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing medullary renal cell 
carcinoma. It is a rare, highly aggressive neoplasm and is morphologically similar to collecting duct 
carcinoma. The hypoxic microenvironment in the renal medulla created by hyperosmolarity, low pH, and 
stasis enhances red blood sickling and ischemic damage. This leads to chronic regenerative 
proliferation of medullary epithelium and activation of hypoxia-induced signaling 
pathways, which in turn promote neoplastic change. The histological section of renal medullary carcinoma showing prominent cytological atypia is 
shown below: 839 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A pathologist is studying the histopathological slide from a nephrectomy specimen from a 
patient with renal carcinoma. He observes neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm and papillary 
architecture. Which of the following subtypes of renal carcinoma is this likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Xp11 translocation carcinoma contains neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm with a papillary 
architecture on histopathology. It is also associated with Psammoma bodies. This condition is caused by translocations of the TFE3 gene located on Xp11.2, which results in 
overexpression of the TFE3 transcription factor. It often occurs in young patients and is 
associated with a poor prognosis. The histological section of Xp11 translocation carcinoma is given below: 840 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding renal cell carcinoma?

options.a: It can invade the renal vein
options.c: It may arise from the proximal convoluted tubule

questions.explanation:
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is more common among males, with a male to female ratio of 2:1. Renal cell carcinoma may arise from the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT). The classical clinical 
features of renal cell carcinoma are costovertebral pain, palpable mass, and painless hematuria. It 
characteristically invades the renal vein and has a high tendency for distant metastasis. Paraneoplastic manifestations of renal cell carcinoma include: • Polycythemia • Hypercalcemia • Hypertension • Hepatic dysfunction 841 
Sold by @itachibot • Feminization or masculinization • Cushing syndrome • Eosinophilia • Leukemoid reactions • Amyloidosis

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation: The most common site of metastasis in renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the lung (more than 50%). Common sites of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma in descending order are: • Lungs • Bones - osteolytic lesions • Regional lymph nodes • Liver • Adrenals • Brain

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis?
questions.explanation: Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis of all renal cell carcinoma subtypes. The renal cell carcinoma subtypes with poor prognosis in descending order are • Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma • Medullary renal cell carcinoma • Clear cell renal cell carcinoma Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma has the best prognosis.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following genes is not mutated in familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes?
questions.explanation:
WT gene is mutated in Wilms' tumor, not renal cell carcinoma. The following gene mutations are associated with familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes: • C-met proto-oncogene • Fumarate hydratase gene • BHD gene • VHL gene 842 
Sold by @itachibot • TSC1 gene • PTEN gene

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following pairs correctly describes the immunohistochemical property of renal 
cell carcinoma in a cancer of unknown origin?
questions.explanation:
Renal cell carcinoma is CK7 negative and CK20 negative. The most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma is clear-cell renal cell carcinoma, which is CK7 
negative. Therefore, in determining the origin of cancer of unknown primary, 
immunohistochemistry (IHC) expression of renal cell carcinoma will generally be CK7 negative 
and CK20 negative. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and papillary renal cell carcinoma are 
positive for CK7. 843 
Sold by @itachibot Lower Urinary Tract
